content.value_statement: This template provides the foundation for building new Claude skills. It includes the required structure and documentation format so developers can focus on implementing functionality rather than configuring boilerplate.
actual_capabilities: Provides standardized SKILL.md format with YAML frontmatter
Defines skill metadata including name, description, and category
Includes tags for skill marketplace discoverability
Documents supported AI tools (Claude, Codex, Claude Code)
Sets up best practices for skill documentation
limitations: This is a template only - no functional code included
Requires complete replacement of placeholder content
Users must add all implementation logic themselves

best_practices: Replace all placeholder content with specific skill details before publishing
Choose the most relevant category for your skill's primary function
Add 3-5 specific tags that describe your skill's function and use case for optimal discoverability
anti_patterns: Publishing without replacing the placeholder description
Leaving the template name instead of a descriptive skill name

faq.question: What tools support this template?
faq.answer: The template works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. All three platforms recognize the SKILL.md format.

faq.question: Can I modify the template structure?
faq.answer: Yes, the template is a starting point. Adapt the structure to fit your skill's specific requirements.

faq.question: Is this skill functional?
faq.answer: No, this is a template only. It provides documentation and structure but no executable functionality.

faq.question: How do I publish a skill?
faq.answer: Fill in all placeholder fields, test your implementation, then submit through the skill marketplace submission process.

faq.question: What license should I use?
faq.answer: Choose an appropriate open source license. MIT, Apache 2.0, and CC0 are common choices for skill templates.

faq.question: How many tags should I add?
faq.answer: Add 3-5 specific tags that describe your skill's function and use case for optimal discoverability.
